His party was further strengthened book by Sohemus ( ), who joined the league v v * with the whole weight of his kingdom, and s s.' also by Antiochus, who inherited immense treasures from his ancestors, and was, of all the kings who submitted to the autho- rity of Rome, the most rich and powerful. Agrippa, who was then at Rome, received private expresses from the East, request- ing his presence in his own country. He departed, before Vitellius had any intelli- gence, and by a quick navigation passed over into Asia. Queen Berenice, at that time flourishing in the bloom of youth, and no less, distinguished by the graces of her person, espoused the interest of Vespasian, to whom, notwithstanding his advanced age, she had made herself agreeable by magnficent presents. The several mari- time provinces, with Asia and Achaia, and the whole inland country between Pontus and the two Armenias, entered into the general confederacy; but from the go- vernors of those provinces no forces could be expected, as they were not, at that time, strengthened by the legions stationed in Cappadocia.
